instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00138: What is 820-00138? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan Spin > Restart > High Fan
threads.message:
I don't know where to start on this one.

I have the pdf but no bv. grrrr

green/amber charger
vcore, g3h, 342, present, warm processor

no backlight
no bootchime

fans spin up for 10 seconds or so, stop, spin up again to high fan. I don't know if that is the regular startup routine similar to <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> etc.

coils above processor seem unusually warm, I could be mistaken.

Any leads would be appreciated.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan Spin > Restart > High Fan
threads.message:
Any history available?
Check for USB activity when board stays on.
You can try new BIOS, with clean ME; don't forget to save your backup...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan Spin > Restart > High Fan
threads.message: Oh man, sorry, yes Liquid damage. Bios seems really clean visually.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan Spin > Restart > High Fan
threads.message:
"yes Liquid damage"
Where was the spill?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan Spin > Restart > High Fan
threads.message: looks like a keyboard spill and some thru the back vent, corrosion near the keyboard backlit connector. board was run through the USC. Damn, sorry not providing important details.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan Spin > Restart > High Fan
threads.message: Need some momentum on this one, please help.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan Spin > Restart > High Fan
threads.message:
"Check for USB activity when board stays on."
Try the board on the desk with nothing connected, apart of USB mouse.
Better to use OSX pendrive witk link LED; if flashes, 100% USB activity confirmed.

"You can try new BIOS, with clean ME"
Did you do it?

Fan goes high normal, if trackpad is not connected.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan Spin > Restart > High Fan
threads.message:
No apparent USB activity.

1) USB Mouse will light up
2) USB Mem Stick with LED - NO access light. Verified Mem stick will blink on other Mac.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan Spin > Restart > High Fan
threads.message:
Post voltages for all big coils (secondary supplies).
Any reaction at pins 1, 7, 3 of <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan Spin > Restart > High Fan
threads.message: CPU power supply circuit getting hot + liquid through back vents and to KBD BL conn. (right by <SIGNAL>S5_HS</SIGNAL>) + high-fans/no chime = dead CPU. You can confirm by checking all the usuals, but this one's going to be dead.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan Spin > Restart > High Fan
threads.message: As soon as I touched the coils that was my thinking, just needed another brain to confirm. thx.
